bioghist.head: Biographical Information
bioghist.p: Abner W. Clopton (1784-1833) was a Baptist minister in Charlotte County. In 1827, Clopton was appointed Georgia state fund-raising agent for Colombian College (later George Washington University), founded by Baptist missionary Luther Rice and chartered in 1821. Due to his success in raising funds for the financially strapped college, Clopton was appointed to its Board of Trustees in 1829 and general agent in 1832. After Clopton's death, Colombian College sued in chancery court in Charlotte County, Virginia, to recover a conditional bequest to the college included in Clopton's will. The court ruled against the college in 1843, and Court of Appeals upheld the decision in 1850.

Abner Wentworth Clopton Terry (1815-1851) was the son of Daniel Terry, one of Clopton's executors, and the grandson of Abner W. Clopton. The other executors named in the will were Archibald A. Davis and John W. Roach. Terry died suddenly in June 1851. He was killed by James D. Saunders, who also died in the confrontation. Saunders was angry about an editorial printed in the Lynchburg Virginian newspaper (Terry was a publisher of the newspaper).

Conway Robinson was a legal scholar and Virginia Court of Appeals court reporter in 1842 and 1843. Between 1846 and 1849, he and acting Governor John M. Patton worked on revisions to the Code of Virginia. The revisions, adopted by the General Assembly in 1849, remained in use for nearly forty years.
Benjamin Watkins Leigh (1781-1849) was a Richmond lawyer and politician. He prepared the 1819 revised code of Virginia and was a court reporter for the Court of Appeals from 1829 to 1841.
James Wood Bouldin (1792-1854) was a lawyer who practiced at Charlotte County Courthouse beginning in 1813. He represented Colombian College in the chancery suit against Clopton's administrators.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of six letters to Abner C.W. Terry, a copy of a letter from Terry to Conway Robinson, about the court case, Colombian College v. Clopton's Administrators, etc., upheld by the Virginia Court of Appeals in December 1850. ; and a manuscript copy of bill of complaint, undated, from a Pittsylvania County chancery cause (Administrator of Nancy Waldr on v. Administrator of Daniel Terry, etc.), seeking distribution of the Clopton legacy to his nieces and nephews. The court document includes genealogical information about the nieces and nephews, their spouses, and their children.

The first letter, dated 1842 Mar. 28, is from Archibald A. Davis, one of the executors named in Clopton's will, discussing the status o the estate and the claim against it by Colobmian College. The second letter, dated 1843 Apr 24, is from Wood Bouldin, attorney for Colombian College in the Charlotte County chancery cause, giving notice to Terry about depositions taken in Washington, D.C. "to prove compliance with the conditions of the bond and will." The third letter, dated 1843 Dec. 10, is from Richmond attorney Benjamin Watkins Leigh offering his services and those of Conway Robinson to Terry should the Colombian College case come before the Court of Appeals.

There are two letters from attorney Conway Robinson about the legal issues in the case Conway Robinson, and one letter from Terry to Robinson. On 1844 June 29, Terry wrote Robinson seeking his opinion about the ultimate disposition of the bequest to the college, noting he had heard that Judge Lee's opinion in the Charlotte County in his favor was "a very ingenious one." On 1844 Jul. 18, Robinson wrote to Terry advising him that the college has obtained an appeal of the Charlotte County case and confirming that he and Leigh would serve as counsel for the appellees. Robinson wrote about possible arguments for the case and cited legal precedents he had used successfully before the court in other cases. On 1851 Apr. 15, after the Court of Appeals upheld the lower court decision in favor of Clopton's administrators, Robinson wrote Terry acknowledging receipt of his fee and advising him about the best way to resolve the distirubtion of the Clopton legacy among the three remaining interests: the nieces and nephews named in the will, Newton Institute, a Baptist instituion in Massachusetts; or the next of kin. He suggests the best way to resolve the issue woudl be to have one interest file suit against the other two interests. The last two items in the collection are a letter from John M. Waldron to Terry, 1851 Mar. 19, advising that he is seeking his mother's portion of the Clopton legacy denied by the Court of Appeals to Colobmian College, and a manuscript copy of a bill of complaint filled in Pittyslvania County chancery court by Waldron, 1851, circa.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Charlotte County Chancery Cause, Colombian College v. Administrator of Abner W. Clopton, etc., Charlotte County (Va.) Chancery Causes, 1765-1912 (bulk 1784-1912), 1843-004. Local Government Records Collection, Charlotte County Court Records. The Library of Virginia, Richmond, Virginia. The court case has been digitized and is available through the Library of Virginia's digital collections portal, Virginia Memory. The case documents include a bill of complaint, answers from Terry and Archibald Davis, depositions from Colombian College Trustee James Wood, Trustee and College Treasurer Andrew Rothwell, James L. Edwards, President of the Board of Trustees, and copies of the act incorporating Colombian College charter, and a copy of Clopton's bond to the college.
